stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malware C2 Traffic Observed
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 12 December 2014 a U.S. government department reported observing network activity from compromised hosts. Malware was observed attempting to contact likely command and control (C2) infrastructure.
The malware may attempt the following HTTP GET request over TCP port 8080, using a dynamically generated C2 domain: GET /logon.aspx?Id=<Dynamic base64 data> HTTP/1.1 Accept: text/html, application/xhtml+xml, */* User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 6.1; Trident/5.0) Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Connection: Keep-Alive Pragma: no-cache Cookie: SessionData=<Dynamic base64 encoded data> Host: <C2 domain>:8080
The SessionData string is base64 encoded. The C2 domain for this GET request changes depending on the system date. The C2 domain is suspected of being created using a domain generating algorithm (DGA) seeded by the current epoch or a number calculated with the current epoch. A new C2 domain appears to be selected on a weekly basis. It appears that the frequency and time of change is configurable. The exact algorithm used to calculate the C2 domain is unknown at this time.
Below are two Snort signatures to potentially detect [REDACTED] network traffic originating from compromised hosts:
alert tcp any any -> any [80,443,8080] (msg:"[REDACTED] Implant Beacon_mm.jpg"; flow:established,to_server; content:"GET"; content:"/mm.jpg"; content:"User-Agent|3a 20|Mozilla/5.0 (compatible"; sid:xxxxxxx; rev:1;)
alert tcp any any -> any [80,443,8080] (msg:"[REDACTED] Implant Beacon_logon.aspx?Id="; flow:established,to_server; content:"GET"; content:"/logon.aspx?Id="; content:"application/x-www-form-urlencoded"; content:"Cookie|3a 20|SessionData="; sid:xxxxxxx; rev:1;
Below is a potential YARA signature to detect [REDACTED] binaries on host machines:
rule [REDACTED]_String { strings: $STR1 = "MAXADDONCMD" wide ascii condition: (uint16(0) == 0x5A4D or uint16(0) == 0xCFD0 or uint16(0) == 0xC3D4 or uint32(0) == 0x46445025 or uint32(1) == 0x6674725C) and all of them }
Import section hashes for the malware that have been observed in different instances include:
03DEF2E0A1DFD5A77CB9EFEF27FEDCF0 A088B642941D6DE58704A9C0A7E65DC5 F8F3B1D366BD893D9D2EBEAE49D2CCC7 6B388E900631EF648715FCF72118513D

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:

GET /<32 Characters> HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/6.0) Host: backup.vmtray.net Connection: Keep-Alive
